newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - June 2.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - June 2.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Monday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Gencor is reported to be planning to separate its nongold and gold interests, to transfer management of its majority nongold interests to a London-registered company and to raise between 600 million pounds and 1.2 billion pounds to fund expansion, mostly international.

- U.S. drug companies plan to make the issue of Health Minister Nkosazana Zuma's draft Medicines and Related Substances Control Amendment Bill a hot issue when Deputy President Thabo Mbeki arrives for the U.S.-S.A. Binational Commission next month.

- Eurorand bond issues had been "extremely positive" for the rand exchange rate and were helping to keep the currency stable, Reserve Bank international banking general manager Bertus van Zyl said on Friday.

- Gencor, the mining house, may split into two separate companies, with its precious metals and base metals divisions divided and a new $5 billion to $7 billion company floated on the London Stock Exchange around subsidiary Billiton International, British newspapers reported yesterday.

- The Reserve Bank is considering reducing its role as the main marketer of South Africa's gold production abroad and increasing the participation of the private sector by the end of the year, industry executives said yesterday.
- James Motlatsi, the president of the National Union of Mineworkers warned the mining industry yesterday to consider alternatives to massive job cuts or face a nationwide industry strike.

- Sappi, the paper and pulp producer, yesterday reported a slump in profit for the half-year to March 31, with attributable profit coming in at 31.5 million rand, less than a tenth of the previous interim period's 356.3 million rand.
- Gencor is shortly going to register its foreign mining interest in a new company on the London Stock Exchange.

- The nation-wide strike by Cosatu is as much against the government's macro-economic strategy (GEAR) as it is against the concept of the basic employment standards, Zwelinzima Vavi Cosatu's assistant secretary-general said yesterday.
- Sappi's net attributable profit for the six months-ended March 31, fell from 356.4 million rand previously to 31.5 million rand.
- Police, army and traffic officials are expecting at least 50,000 people to take part in today's Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) march through Johannesburg's city centre.
- The failure of Johannesburg's Eastern council to pass its budget is likely to cause huge political embarrasment to the ANC-led Greater Johannesburg council and the Gauteng government.
